title: Settings table design
text: full list variables (settings) can included settings file. necessary variables function included section function. variable (string): call variable final dataset type (string): specific strings trigger specific function calls; others ignored options (string): options categorical variables, separate option row probability_1 (number): likelihood item selected, based function sample() labels (string): labels use values select-many type questions probability_2 (number): likelihood item selected second () run select-many type questions, based function sample() min_val (number): minimum allowed value selections based normal distribution max_val (number): maximum allowed value selections based normal distribution mean_val (number): mean value selections based normal distribution sd_val (number): standard deviation selections based normal distribution max_opts (integer): maximum possible number selections select-many options miss_pct (number): percentage responses expected contain missing values

title: Settings table design
text: categorical data one item selected, table contain following settings: variable, type, options, probability_1, miss_pct. settings ignored. illustration, first create simple data frame settings. Table 1. Example settings single item selection categorical data dataset created, run select_categorical_set() function, wrapper sample_one() function allows generate multiple variables , dataset contains many single item selection questions. Table 2. Example single item selection categorical data
code: cat1 <- data.frame(   variable = "my_letters", # variable name in final dataset   type = "select-one",     # string that triggers `select_categorical_set()`   options = letters[1:5],  # value options   probability_1 = 1:5,     # proportions or probabilities (need not sum to 100)   miss_pct = 10            # percentage of missing values expected (between 0 and 100) ) cat1data <- select_categorical_set(d = cat1, count = 5)

title: Settings table design
text: categorical data multiple items can selected, table contain following settings: variable, type, options, probability_1, probability_2, labels, max_opts, miss_pct. settings ignored. illustration, first create simple data frame settings. Table 3. Example settings multiple item selection categorical data dataset created, run select_many_set() function, wrapper sample_many() function allows generate multiple variables , dataset contains many multiple item selection questions. Table 4. Example multiple item selection categorical data
code: cat2 <- data.frame(   variable = "my_letters", # variable name in final dataset   type = "select-many",    # string that triggers `select_many_set()`   options = letters[1:5],  # value options   probability_1 = 1:5,     # proportions or probabilities (need not sum to 100)   miss_pct = 5,            # percentage of missing values expected (between 0 and 100)   labels = letters[1:5],   # value label in the variable (can duplicate "variable")   probability_2 = 5:1,     # proportions or probabilities (can duplicate "probability_1")   max_opts = 3             # maximum allowed responses (could be less) ) cat2data <- select_many_set(d = cat2, count = 5)

title: Settings table design
text: package, continuous data assumed normally distributed, upper lower limits coded missing. function used, select_continuous_set(), tested positive numbers. continuous data, table contain following settings: variable, type, miss_pct, min_val, max_val, mean_val, sd_val. settings ignored. illustration, first create simple data frame settings. Table 5. Example settings continuous data dataset created, run select_continuous_set() function, utilizes truncnorm::rturncnorm() allows generate multiple variables , dataset contains many continuous values response questions. Table 6. Example continuous data function select_continuous_set() rounds responses nearest hundredth. easily changed made function option interest. used function generate normal distribution years, post-processing, rounded nearest integer.
code: cont <- data.frame(   variable = "my_numbers", # variable name in final dataset   type = "normal",         # string that triggers `select_many_set()`   miss_pct = 20,           # percentage of missing values expected (between 0 and 100)   min_val = 0,             # minimum allowed value   max_val = 100,           # maximum allowed value   mean_val = 75,           # mean expected value   sd_val = 10              # expected standard deviation ) contdata <- select_continuous_set(d = cont, count = 5)

title: Settings table design
text: created dates function simulate survey dates, survey available short range time day equal chance chosen. want random sample birth dates, function used , intent. date data, table contain following settings: variable, type, miss_pct, min_val, max_val. settings ignored. illustration, first create simple data frame settings. Table 7. Example settings date data dataset created, run select_dates_set() function, allows generate multiple variables , dataset contains many date response questions. Table 8. Example date data
code: date <- data.frame(   variable = "my_dates", # variable name in final dataset   type = "date",         # string that triggers `select_many_set()`   miss_pct = 20,         # percentage of missing values expected (between 0 and 100)   min_val = "6/1/2025",  # earliest allowed date ("yyyy-mm-dd" format also accepted)   max_val = "8/31/2025"  # latest allowed date ("yyyy-mm-dd" format also accepted) ) datedata <- select_dates_set(d = date, count = 5)

title: Settings table design
text: created internet protocol (IP) address function request simulate random IP addresses. IP addresses vary geography. function assumes total randomness, geography important, may want clone modify fit needs. function run using settings table. takes one input, number responses. produces one variable, “ip_address”. Table 9. Example IP address data

title: Settings table design
text: created age function meet specific needs, required incorrect ages data validation exercise. result, function generates age two dates (case, birth date survey date), includes option add error. added missingness age variable using start end date variables contained missingness. function run using settings table. takes three inputs, start date, end date, whether include error. variable returned age. example , dates date example 2025, ages 25 unless introduce error. Table 10. Frequency table age data errors
code: # since the chance of error is low, we will artificially increase the number of records end_dates = rep(datedata$my_dates, 10) # enter 50 end dates instead of 5 age <- sample_age(start_date = "2000-01-01", end_date = end_dates, error = TRUE)

title: Create Toy Survey Data
text: R package designed simplify process creating fake survey data.

title: Create Toy Survey Data
text: R package began project create simple fake dataset based annual Community Health Assessment surveys. preparing give presentation cleaning validating survey data, access real survey data, privacy confidentiality major concerns. reviewed existing survey creation packages, either allow level customization needed used models read real data, , starting point.

title: Create Toy Survey Data
text: package built initially generate responses individual categorical questions based priori knowledge response proportions. numeric variable date handling added later, mostly based normal distributions. functions can used individually, package designed allow build settings table, run functions table generate full dataset.

title: Create Toy Survey Data
text: package designed simple. consider relationships variables. includes optional missingness, include error creation.

title: Create Toy Survey Data
text: package still active development, may get errors try install directly GitHub. meantime, clone package run devtools::load_all() load use functions. (: finish setting package installable.) create dataset, need read table settings specific format. package designed table set correctly, can run functions one table. (: add link vignette, set pkgdown.)

title: Calculate multiple booleans — sample_many
text: function provides maximum allowed number responses. responses less "miss_pct" greater zero, responses selections.

title: Calculate multiple booleans — sample_many
text: var string; variable name d dataset; contains labels probabilities count integer; number responses (rows)

title: Calculate multiple booleans — sample_many
code: d <- data.frame(variable = "my_letters", type = "select-many", miss_pct = 10,                 options = letters[1:5], labels = letters[1:5], max_opts = 3,                 probability_1 = 9:5, probability_2 = 1:5)  sample_many(var = "my_letters", d = d, count = 10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 6 #>       id c     e     a     d     b     #>    <int> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> #>  1     1 c     NA    a     NA    b     #>  2     2 c     NA    a     NA    NA    #>  3     3 NA    e     a     d     NA    #>  4     4 NA    e     NA    d     NA    #>  5     5 c     NA    a     d     NA    #>  6     6 NA    NA    NA    d     b     #>  7     7 c     e     NA    NA    b     #>  8     8 c     NA    NA    d     NA    #>  9     9 c     e     NA    d     NA    #> 10    10 c     NA    NA    NA    b

text: options vector strings; value options probs vector numbers; probability options count integer; number responses (rows) Create vector values based pre-defined choices probabilities. can also program certain percent missing values. miss_pct number 0 100; percent responses expected missing

title: Create a random vector of responses — sample_one
code: sample_one(options = letters[1:3], probs = 1:3, count = 10, miss_pct = 20) #>  [1] "c" "c" NA  "c" "b" "c" "b" "c" "a" "b"

title: Add sampling data errors — sampling_error
text: var Vector values modified type Type data vector: accepts "character" "numeric"

title: Add sampling data errors — sampling_error
code: d <- data.frame(x = signif(rnorm(10000, mean = 0, sd = 100), digits = 4)) d$y <- sampling_error(d$x) #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `var = dplyr::case_when(...)`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! NaNs produced
